text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the official Vietnamese press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet had called for stricter measures to prevent possible damage during the coming storm season by moving people from areas prone to landslides and floods.
-- Vietnam will give support to Vietnamese living in other countries for their own community activities as soon as Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet receives recommendations of how to do it.
-- State-owned Vietnam Coal Corporation's output was 3.2 million tonnes in the first four months of 1997.
-- The finance ministry has ordered entities which draw on the state budget to open accounts at the State Treasury so that their financial activities can be managed more efficiently.

-- There has been a breakthrough in talks between the Vietnam Post and Telecommunication company, France Telecom, NTT, Telstra and Cable & Wireless, paving the way for implementation of a long-conceived $1.2 billion programme to develop the telephone system in Vietnam.
-- Minister of Science, Technology and Environment Pham Gia Khiem has been appointed head of a state management board on Internet.
-- Vietnam biggest sugar mill, with capacity of 6,000 tonnes of sugar cane per day, started operation in northern province of Thanh Hoa.
-- Vietnam has set up a governmental team to negotiate and prepare for joining the World Trade Organization.
-- State budget revenues reached 26.2 percent of the 1997 target in the first four months of the year.
-- Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet said drug traffickers will be seeking to expand their market in the next century by getting more teenagers to use drugs.
